entry.summary: WhatWelcome to this blog documenting my learning journey into the "cryptoverse", or…
entry.content:
What

Welcome to this blog documenting my learning journey into the "cryptoverse", or the rabbit hole that is blockchain security.

I will focus primarily on:

  • Blockchain security in general (blockchain or protocol agnostic)
  • Smart contract security & audits
  • Risks related to decentralized finance (DeFi)
  • Ethereum security & Ethereum virtual machine (EVM)
  • Etc.

Please make sure to use the tags to filter through the various subjects.

The more you know, the more you realize you don't know.

Why

There is currently an extreme shortage of knowledgeable security professionals in the job market, and I reckon the shortage in the field of blockchain security is even more pressing.

Since sharing is caring, I hope to inspire others with my (albeit nascent) knowledge, and information I have come across through my searches on the internet.Â 

I hope this blog helps you on your journey ğŸ™

entry.title: DAO governance attacks, and how to avoid them (az16 crypto)
entry.summary: A nice coop by Pranav Garimidi, Scott Duke Kominers and Tim Roughgarden:…
entry.content:
A nice coop by Pranav Garimidi, Scott Duke Kominers and Tim Roughgarden:Â  https://a16zcrypto.com/dao-governance-attacks-and-how-to-avoid-them/Â 

From the article:

Many web3 projects embrace permissionless voting using a fungible and tradable native token. Permissionless voting can offer many benefits, from lowering barriers to entry to increasing competition. Token holders can use their tokens to vote on a range of issuesâ€”from simple parameter adjustments to the overhaul of the governance process itself. (For a review of DAO governance, see â€œLightspeed Democracy.â€)Â But permissionless voting is vulnerable to governance attacks, in which an attacker acquires voting power through legitimate means (e.g., buying tokens on the open market) but uses that voting power to manipulate the protocol for the attackerâ€™s own benefit. These attacks are purely â€œin-protocol,â€ which means they canâ€™t be addressed through cryptography. Instead, preventing them requires thoughtful mechanism design. To that end, weâ€™ve developed a framework to help DAOs assess the threat and potentially counter such attacks.Â 

It is an attack which is less prevalent than phishing, but they can be devastating nonetheless (e.g. DAO treasuries getting emptied).

entry.content:
Michael Blau released his detector for metamorphic smart contracts:Â  https://a16zcrypto.com/metamorphic-smart-contract-detector-tool/

A critical Ethereum security assumption is that smart contract code is immutable and therefore cannot be changed once it is deployed on the blockchain. In practice, some smart contracts can change â€“ even after theyâ€™ve been deployed. With a few clever tricks, you can create metamorphic smart contracts that â€œmetamorphoseâ€ into something else â€“ and by understanding what makes them possible, you can detect them.

Ethereum Smart Contract Security Best Practices

  • Development Recommendations contains examples of good code patterns
  • Known Attacks describes the different classes of vulnerabilities to avoid
  • Security Tools lists tools for improving code quality, and detecting vulnerabilities
  • Bug Bounties List of bug bounties in the ecosystem.
